title: How to Get Salt to Stick to Margarita Glasses

steps.headline: Sprinkle a tablespoon or two of coarse salt into a small serving plate.
steps.description: You can also measure a 50-50 ratio of salt and sugar, as this gives a sweet taste.

steps.headline: Wet the rim (or lip) of the glass with a fruit wedge.
steps.description: The most popular choice to use are limes, mainly for margaritas. Lemons, oranges, and other citrus fruits can also be used.

steps.headline: Dip all sides of the rim into the salt by lightly swirling the glass.
Turn the glass upright.
steps.description: Pour your drink into the salted rim glass, garnish it with additional fruit wedges, and enjoy.

text: Sprinkle a tablespoon or two of coarse salt into a small serving plate. You can also measure a 50-50 ratio of salt and sugar, as this gives a sweet taste. Wet the rim (or lip) of the glass with a fruit wedge. The most popular choice to use are limes, mainly for margaritas. Lemons, oranges, and other citrus fruits can also be used. Turn the glass upside down.  Dip all sides of the rim into the salt by lightly swirling the glass.  Turn the glass upright. Pour your drink into the salted rim glass, garnish it with additional fruit wedges, and enjoy.
